questions.question: A 28 y/o reports a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago but is otherwise healthy. She does not smoke and has no other significant medical history. She desires a reliable, long-term contraceptive method. Which of the following contraceptive options is MOST contraindicated in this patient?
questions.explanation: contraceptive option in this scenario is COCPs due to the patient's history of DVT and the associated risk of thromboembolic events with estrogen-containing contraceptives. Adverse Effects of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) Contraindications of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) Cardiovascular Effects (due to estrogen content) Myocardial infarction (MI) Cerebral thrombosis - Stroke Risk increases with age >35 and cigarette smoking. Carcinogenesis Increased risk of cervical cancer Metabolic Effects (due to progesterone content) Elevated blood pressure Altered serum lipid levels Interference with blood clotting Interference with carbohydrate metabolism Thromboembolic Events Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) Pulmonary embolism (PE) Others Lactation: Reduced quantity and quality of breast milk Weight gain Migraine Breast tenderness Absolute Contraindications: Cancer of the breast and genitals Liver disease Previous or present history of thromboembolism Cardiac abnormalities Congenital hyperlipidaemia DM with vasculopathy Migraine with aura Undiagnosed vaginal bleed Suspected pregnancy Relative Contraindications (requiring medical surveillance): Age over 40 years Smoking and age over 35 years Mild hypertension Chronic renal disease Migraine Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no. 576, 577

questions.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic of a planned family?

options.A: No childbirth beyond the age of 30-35
options.B: Gap of 2 years between marriage and first child birth
options.C: Age of mother is >20 years at the time of first child birth
options.D: Gap of 2 years between 2 successive pregnancies

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Gap of 2 years between 2 successive pregnancies Explanation: In a planned family the gap between two successive pregnancies should be atleast 3 years. Terms Used in Family Planning: Planned family: The birth of the first child should be delayed till the mother is 20 years old (option C). No child birth after the age of 30-35 years (option A). The ideal gap between marriage and first child birth should be 2 years (option B). There should be a gap of atleast 3 years between 2 successive pregnancies (option D). No unwanted pregnancies. Should have a limited family size. Eligible Couple: It is defined as, currently married couples wherein the wife is of reproductive age group (15-49 years). Around 150-180 eligible couples per 1000 population in India. Around 20% of eligible couples are found in age groups between 15-24 years. Eligible couple register is found at the sub-centre maintained by ANM. Target Couple: Not in use now It is defined as, a married couple who completed their family or having at least 1 child. Family planning is largely directed towards such couples. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no. 567

questions.question: In a village with a population of 2,000 eligible couples, the survey findings revealed that 600 couples use oral contraceptives, 300 couples use condoms, 200 couples use intrauterine devices (IUDs), and 100 couples have undergone sterilization. Which of the following is the couple protection rate (CPR)?
questions.explanation: using contraception is: 600+300+200+100=1200 The total number of eligible couples = 2000 Therefore, CPR= (1200/2000)x100=60% (option D) Couple Protection Rate: It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples protected against childbirth by using one or other approved contraceptive methods. CPR is the indicator of the prevalence of contraceptive practices in the community. The demographic goal of NRR=1, can be achieved only when the CPR is >60%. The current couple protection rate in India is 66.7%. Effective couple protection rate: It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by using one or other approved contraceptive methods. It takes into account the relative efficacies of different contraceptives. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 567

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly defines the Pearl Index for measuring contraceptive effectiveness?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pregnancies per 100 Woman-Years Explanation: The Pearl Index is calculated as the number of pregnancies that occur per 100 woman-years of exposure to a contraceptive method. It is a technique for evaluating contraceptive efficacy. Formula (Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure) x 1200 Numerator The total number of accidental pregnancies, including pregnancies that resulted in live births, stillbirths, abortions, or are ongoing. Denominator (Total months in the review period) – (months stopped using contraception for non-pregnancy reasons) Minimum Data At least 600 months of exposure. Disadvantages PI assumes a constant failure rate over time, but contraceptive failure rates typically decline with longer use. High-fertility couples conceive earlier, skewing results towards lower-fertility couples later in studies. PI ignores factors beyond accidental pregnancy that affect effectiveness, like user dissatisfaction, side effects, attempts to conceive, or loss of follow-up. Better methods Life Table Analysis is a better method to evaluate contraceptive efficacy. It calculates cumulative failure rates over a specified time frame, like one month. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 585

questions.question: Match the following contraceptive methods with their appropriate failure rates. Contraceptive Failure Rate A. Male condom 1. 9-20/HWY B. Female Condom 2. 20-40/HWY C. Diaphragm 3. 6-12/HWY D. Vaginal sponge (Nulliparous women) 4. 2-14/HWY E. Vaginal sponge (Parous women) 5. 5-21/HWY
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A-4, B-5, C-3, D-1, E-2 Explanation: Contraceptive Method Failure Rate (Pregnancies per 100 women-years) Additional Information Male Condom 2-13 The most common cause of failure is incorrect use. Female Condom 5-21 Higher failure rate than male condoms. Diaphragm 6-12 Not recommended under the National Family Planning Welfare Programme. Vaginal sponge 9-20 Higher failure rate in parous women (20-40/HWY) compared to nulliparous women. Spermicides High High failure rate when used alone, but good to use with some other contraceptive method. Failure rates of other contraceptive methods: Method Pregnancies per 100 women years Injectables 0.05 Implant 0.1 Vasectomy 0.1 OCP 0.3 Hormonal IUD 0.5 Tubal ligation 0.5 Copper IUD 0.6 Calendar method 14 Withdrawal 20 Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and social medicine, 27th edition, Page 569-570. https://cdn.who.int/media /docs/default-source/reproductive-health/contraception-family-planning/mechanisms-of-action-and-effectiveness-of- contraception-methods.pdf?sfvrsn=e39a69c2_1

questions.question: Match the following: a) Mission Parivar Vikas 1) Contraception counselling method b) NISCHAY 2) Population stabilization fund c) Jansankhya sthirata kosh 3) Nayi pahel kit- family planning kit for newly weds d) Gather approach 4) Home testing UPT provided by ASHA
questions.explanation: and reduce the population Nayi pahel kit- family planning kit for newlyweds Saas bahu samelan- encourages daughter-in-law and mother-in-law to discuss family planning Saarthi- family planning mobile van NISCHAY Home testing UPT provided by ASHA Jansankhya sthirata kosh Population stabilization fund Gather approach Contraception counselling method Stands for Greet, Ask, Tell, Help, Explain, and Return

questions.question: What program is the given image a logo for?
questions.explanation: Family Welfare Program Themes: Son or daughter: Two will do Second child should be after 3 years of first child Universal immunization Community needs assessment approach Targets: Couple protection Rate should be more than 60% Total fertility rate (TFR) has to be achieved 2.1 Net reproduction rate (NRR) to be achieved 1 Current TFR of India= 2.0 and CPR =66.7%

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman with 3 children has come for counselling regarding sterilisation. She is hesitant to have surgery. Which of the following methods suits her needs?
questions.explanation: insertion of Essure device through the vagina into the fallopian tubes. There is causes scar tissue formation and occludes the fallopian tubes This is confirmed by hysterosalpingogram Done in the USA Can cause pain, displacement, expulsion, and unintended pregnancy Hulka clips are another form of non-surgical sterilisation in women The clip is placed over the fallopian tube to occlude it Option B: DMPA - is an injectable form of birth control called ANTARA. It is not a method of sterilisation. Option C: Mesigyna - 50 mg norethisterone enanthate plus 5 mg oestradiol valerate is a newer form of oral contraception. Option D: Cerazette - is a progesterone-only pill

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding female sterilisation?

options.A: Minilap can be performed at PHC level
options.B: Permission of spouse must be obtained
options.D: They must be of age 22-49 years

questions.explanation: Married or has been married (Option C) Age 22-49 years (Option D) At least one child over age 1 year Spouse must not have undergone sterilization procedure Consenting Permission of spouse not necessary (Option B) Who can perform the procedure: Minilap by trained MBBS doctor Laparoscopic sterilization (admitted for observation for 24 hours) by DGO (Diploma Gynaecologist), MD (Gyn-obs), or MS (Surgery) Procedure and timing: Procedure Timing Interval sterilization Any time after 6 weeks of childbirth Postpartum sterilization Between 24 hours to 7 days of delivery Sterilization with MTP Concurrently Sterilisation following spontaneous abortion Within 7 days (if no other complications) Types of operation: Laparoscopic- procedure is done after 6 weeks postpartum or concurrently with MTP Minilap- smaller incisions than laparoscopic procedure and easier to perform at PHC. (Option A) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th ed Pg 585-6 https://cghealth.nic.in/dhs/NEW%2 0OFFERINGS-FP%20GUIDELINES/Ref%20Manual%20for%20Female%20Sterilization%202014.pdf

questions.question: A 40-year-old male is ready for discharge after vasectomy under his family planning program. How long should he use additional contraceptive measures till he becomes completely sterile?

options.A: No need of additional contraceptive measures

questions.explanation: males. It is a single time method, which does not require prolonged motivation for its effectiveness. Guidelines for Vasectomy: The age of the husband should be 25-50 yrs. The couple should have 2 living children. If the couple has 3 or more children, then the lower limit of age can be relaxed. Procedure: Postoperative advice: Must use alternate methods of contraception for 30 ejaculations after the procedure to ensure sterility (option C). Should keep the surgical area clean Should not lift weights

questions.question: In the Basal body temperature method, which of the following is the reason for increase in body temperature?
questions.explanation: Calendar/Rhythm method Intercourse should be avoided on 11th to 17th day of menstrual cycle Ova remains viable for 12-24 hrs. Not preferred since menstrual cycles are not always regular. Basal Body Temperature method: Prior to ovulation, the basal body temperature increases by 0.3 to 0.5 degree Celsius. The increase in temperature is due to an increase in progesterone (Option B). This method is reliable if the intercourse is restricted to the post ovulatory phase, after 3 days of temperature rise. Cervical mucus/Billings method: This method is based on changes in characteristics of cervical mucus observed as the menstrual cycle proceeds. During ovulation, cervical mucus becomes watery, smooth, slippery and profuse resembling raw egg white. After ovulation, cervical mucus thickens and decreases in quantity, due to increase in progesterone. This method requires a high level of motivation.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an emergency contraceptive?
questions.explanation: effective as an emergency contraceptive. This differentiates it from the other options, which are all used specifically for emergency contraception. Drugs used in emergency contraception: Emergency contraception MOA How to use(hrs after unprotected sexual intercourse) Copper containing IUD (most effective) Causes a chemical reaction and prevents fertilization Should be inserted within 120 hours (99% effective) Levonorgestrel (i-pill) (option C) Progesterone thickens cervical mucus and decreases tubal motility 1.5 mg single tablet or two doses of 0.75 mg 12 hours apart within 72 hours Ulipristal (option A) Selective progesterone receptor down regulator 30 mg single tablet within 120 hours Mifepristone (option B) Makes endometrium unsuitable for implantation 10 mg single dose within 72 hours Yuzpee method (not used now) Prevents implantation and thickens cervical mucus Two doses of 0.1 mg ethinylestradiol and 0.5 mg levonorgestrel, 12 hours apart, within 72 hours Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no: 575 https://www.who.int/new s-room/fact-sheets/detail/emergency-contraception#:~:text=A%20copper%2Dbearing%20IUD%20is,of%20ethinyl %20estradiol%20plus%20levonorgestrel.

questions.question: A woman missed 2 pills in the second week of her contraceptive pack. She had unprotected sex yesterday. What should she do?

options.A: Discard the pack and start a new one immediately
options.B: Take 2 pills at the scheduled time
options.C: Skip the missed pills and continue with the next pack

questions.explanation: first day of the menstrual cycle and latest by 5th day of the cycle Guidelines of missed OCP’s: Missed pills Management Missed 1 or 2 pills/ started new pack 1 or 2 days late Take one pill as soon as possible or take 2 pills at the scheduled time: No risk of pregnancy Missed 3 or more pills in the first or second week/ started a new pack 3 or more days late Take one pill as soon as possible, and then continue with the scheduled pill Use the backup method for the next 7 days In case of unprotected sex in the last 72 hours, use an emergency contraceptive method Missed 3 or more pills in the third week (last week) Take one pill as soon as possible and finish the rest of the hormonal pills The last 7 non – hormonal pills should be discarded, start a new pack the next day Use a barrier method for the next 7 days In case of unprotected sex in the last 7 days, use emergency contraception Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/family-planing/guidelines/Reference_Manual_Oral_Pills.pdf

questions.question: A 30 Y/o woman has been taking oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for the past five years, not just for contraception but also for managing her menstrual cramps and acne. Which of the following are additional long-term health benefits of OCPs, aside from birth control and symptomatic relief?
questions.explanation: hormonal contraceptives consisting of either combined estrogen and progesterone or only progesterone or only estrogen. It prevents ovulation and implantation, decreases tubal motility, and thickens cervical mucus. Benefits of OCP’s: Contraceptive benefits: If taken correctly, they are 100% effective in preventing pregnancy. Non-contraceptive benefits: Decreases the risk of: Benign breast diseases such as fibrocystic disease and fibroadenoma. Ovarian cysts Pelvic inflammatory diseases Ectopic pregnancy Iron deficiency anemia Ovarian cancer (option C) Colon cancer Dysmenorrhea, DUB, irregular menstrual cycles Osteoporosis Option A: OCPs are proven to increase the risk of hypertension in women, which further increases the risk of stroke and myocardial infarction. Option B: Women taking OCPs will have an increased risk of arterial/venous thrombosis due to the estrogen component of the pill. The risk increases with age and if she is a smoker. Option D: OCPs are proven to increase the risk of cervical cancer. The risk increases with the duration of use of OCP’s Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no: 576-577

questions.question: A 30-year-old sexually active couple presents at a free health clinic seeking advice on contraception methods that also protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). They are interested in a method that offers both protection from pregnancy and protection against STDs. Which barrier method would be most recommended for them?
questions.explanation: would be the male condom. Male condoms are highly effective in preventing both pregnancy and the transmission of STIs when used consistently and correctly. They are readily available, easy to use, cost-efficient and do not require a fitting like diaphragms or cervical caps. Feature Male Condom Female Condom Diaphragm Material Latex Polyurethane or Nitrile/latex Synthetic rubber or plastic Spermicide Requirement Optional Pre-lubricated with silicone; spermicide not required Used with spermicide Protection against STDs Protects both partners from STDs Protects against STDs Doesn't protect from HIV and STDs Failure rate 2-13/HWY 5-21/HWY 6-12/HWY Advantages Safe, easy to use, inexpensive, no side effects, easy disposable No Hormonal side effects. Can be used by women with latex sensitivity. Can be reused. Nil side effects and medical contraindications, reusable Disadvantages May slip off or tear due to incorrect use Interferes with sexual sensation Interferes with sexual sensation May slip off or tear High cost, noticeable during sex, needs practice to insert and use Should be present in vagina up to 6 hours post-ejaculation , Risk of Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) if left for > 24 hours Brand Name(s) NIRODH FEMIDOM Variations of diaphragm:Cervical cap, Vault cap, Vimule cap, Dutch cap Availability Freely available under the National Family Welfare Programme Provided under the National AIDS Control Programme (NACP) Not recommended under the National Family Planning Welfare Programme Other Information Should not be reused most Reusable; male and female condoms should not be used together due to an anti-synergistic effect

questions.question: Match the following contraceptive methods with their correct descriptions: Contraceptive Method Description A. Femilon 1. A non-hormonal male contraceptive derived from cottonseed oil. B. Mini Pills 2. A combined oral contraceptive pill containing both estrogen and progesterone. C. Gossypol 3. A progestin-only oral contraceptive pill.
questions.explanation: Target Population Femilon (Combined OCP) Ethinyl estradiol IP (0.02 mg) and Desogestrel BP (0.15 mg) - Ultra low dose Inhibits ovulation by suppressing pituitary secretion of gonadotropin Women Mini pills (Progesterone only pill) Progesterone Inhibits ovulation, thickens cervical mucus, inhibits tubal motility, delays sperm and ovum transport Older women, women who cannot use combined pills due to cardiovascular risks, women who are lactating Gossypol (Non-hormonal male contraceptivel) Natural phenol, a derivative of cotton-seed oil Inhibits spermatogenesis Men Reference: Park’s 27th ed. Page no. 574-576.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the difference between MALA-N and MALA-D?

options.A: MALA-N: Contains only progesterone; MALA-D: Contains both estrogen and progesterone
options.B: MALA-N: Available for free under the government program; MALA-D: Sold at a subsidised price
options.C: MALA-N: Taken daily; MALA-D: Taken weekly
options.D: MALA-N: Injectable contraceptive; MALA-D: Oral contraceptive

questions.explanation: a subsidised price Correct Answer: B Explanation: Feature MALA-N MALA-D Availability (Option B) Supplied free of cost through PHCs, urban family welfare centers. Available at a subsidized price of Rs. 3 per packet through social marketing schemes Composition (Option A) Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and Ethinyl estradiol 0.03 mg Packaging (Option D) Packet of 28 tablets - 21 white pills containing the hormones and 7 brown film-coated tablets containing 60 mg ferrous fumarate Mechanism of action Prevents ovulation Prevents implantation Thick cervical secretions Effectiveness 100% effective if taken correctly Failure rate with typical use is 0.8% Option C: Both MALA-N and MALA-D are taken daily, not weekly.

questions.question: A 38 y/o woman presents to a clinic seeking contraception counseling. She is a breastfeeding mother of a 3-month-old baby. She reports a history of heavy menstrual bleeding. Which of the following can be given to her?
questions.explanation: bleeding, Non-hormonal contraceptive such as Centchroman is advised to the patient. Centchroman (Ormeloxifene) Brand Name Saheli (formerly); Chhaya (currently) Type of Contraceptive Non-hormonal, selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) Mechanism of Action Delays ovulation, alters the endometrial lining to prevent implantation Dosage One 30mg tablet twice a week for the first 3 months, followed by one tablet weekly thereafter Advantages Non-hormonal, minimal side effects Convenient weekly dosage No impact on breastfeeding Protective effect against breast and endometrial cancer. Disadvantages Has a high failure rate attributed to low compliance with the prescribed dosing schedule. Additional Uses Dysfunctional uterine bleeding Contraindications PCOD, Thromboembolic disorders, severe liver dysfunction Availability Included in the National Family Welfare program, making it available free of charge at sub-centers Option A: COCPs are not recommended for breastfeeding mothers, especially during the first six months postpartum, as estrogen can interfere with lactation. COCPs also wouldn’t address her heavy menstrual bleeding. Option B: DMPA can exacerbate irregular menstrual bleeding. Option C: Progesterone-only pills are known for causing irregular bleeding patterns and might not be suitable for this patient.

questions.question: A 28 y/o woman desires a reliable method that she can manage herself and wants to avoid daily pill-taking. She has no history of cardiovascular disease or other contraindications for combined hormonal contraception. Which of the following offers both estrogen and progesterone and would be suitable for this patient?
questions.explanation: that is inserted into the vagina. Contraceptive Method Hormone Type Benefits Form Duration of Effectiveness NuvaRing (Option A) Estrogen (Ethinyl Estradiol) and Progesterone (Etonogestrel) Lower Estrogen exposure than with OCPs. Low incidence of estrogenic S/E. Low incidence of irregular bleeding. Vaginal Ring 1 month ANTARA (Option B) Progesterone (Medroxyprogesterone Acetate) Long-lasting and reversible. Injectable (Depo-Provera) 3 months NORPLANT (Option C) Progesterone (Levonorgestrel) Used during lactation because it has progesterone and no estrogen. Subdermal Implants Up to 5 years NET-EN (Option D) Progesterone (Norethisterone Enanthate) Long-lasting and reversible. Injectable 8 weeks Reference: Review of the combined contraceptive vaginal ring, NuvaRing® - PMC (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents for contraceptive counselling. She has a history of irregular menstrual cycles and desires a long-acting reversible contraceptive method. She is not currently pregnant and has no recent history of pelvic infections. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago, and she is not currently using any form of contraception. When is the most appropriate time for the gynecologist to insert the intrauterine device (IUD) for this patient?

options.C: At any time during her cycle
options.D: Two weeks before her next menstrual period

questions.explanation: insertion is generally during the menstrual period or immediately after (up to the first 10 days of the cycle) because the cervix is more dilated. Note: Menstrual cycle starts from the first day of menses. Timing of IUD insertion: Ideal time During menstruation or within the first 10 days of the start of period Preferred time Postpartum (immediate postpartum): Post-placenta insertion; Has a higher rate of expulsion Late postpartum: Within 48 hours of delivery up to 1 week Other times Post-puerperal: After 6-8 weeks of delivery Post-coital: Up to 3-5 days after unprotected intercourse. Post-abortion: After 1st trimester loss. Not recommended after a 2nd trimester abortion. Reference: Park’s textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 572 https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/emergency-contraception

questions.question: Which of the following is not an absolute contraindication to IUD insertion?
questions.explanation: contraceptive use and national guidelines, the following are absolute contraindications to IUD (intrauterine device) insertion: Condition Contraindication Type Reason Suspected pregnancy (Option A) Absolute Risk of interfering with existing pregnancy Cervical cancer (Ca cervix) (Option B) Absolute Risk of bleeding/infection, treatment takes priority Current pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) (Option D) Absolute IUD could worsen infection and lead to complications Menorrhagia Relative (not absolute) May worsen bleeding, but not a strict contraindication; copper IUDs are avoided, but LNG-IUS (like Mirena) is actually used to treat menorrhagia Absolute Contraindications IUDs must not be inserted in the following situations due to significant risk: Condition Rationale Pregnancy or suspected pregnancy Risk of miscarriage or infection Current pelvic infections (PID, endometritis, TB) Increased risk of exacerbation and spread of infection Mucopurulent cervicitis or untreated STIs Insertion may worsen infection Recent puerperal or septic abortion (<3 months) Higher infection risk Cervical or endometrial cancer May cause trauma or interfere with treatment Gestational trophoblastic disease with elevated β -hCG Risk of uterine perforation or spread Unexplained abnormal vaginal bleeding Need to exclude serious pathology before insertion Uterine abnormalities distorting the cavity Can prevent proper placement and increase risk of perforation Allergy to IUD components e.g., copper allergy (copper IUD), levonorgestrel allergy (hormonal IUD) Wilson’s disease (for copper IUDs) Copper accumulation is contraindicated Current breast cancer (for hormonal IUDs) Hormonal exposure may worsen estrogen-sensitive malignancies Relative Contraindications These conditions require careful risk-benefit analysis before proceeding: Condition Considerations Resolved GTD with falling β -hCG May be safe if levels are undetectable High risk of STIs (e.g., multiple partners) May increase infection risk post-insertion Complicated transplant history May impair immune response or healing Advanced AIDS (not clinically well) Higher infection risk and complications Coagulopathies or severe anemia May worsen bleeding, particularly with copper IUDs Past history of PID, STIs, or ectopic pregnancy Not absolute, but requires counseling and monitoring Certain chronic conditions (e.g., SLE, liver disease) Hormonal IUDs need evaluation of risk of worsening disease Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557403/

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman presents with complaints of persistent lower abdominal pain and fever. She had a copper-releasing intrauterine device inserted nine months ago for contraception. She has multiple sexual partners. On examination, she appears uncomfortable, and her abdomen is tender to palpation in the lower quadrants. Pelvic examination reveals no visible IUD strings. Her vital signs show a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). What is the most likely complication associated with this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) Explanation The patient’s symptoms of fever and lower abdominal pain, along with her history of multiple sexual partners, point to the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease, which is a complication of IUD use. Side effects of IUDs: Side effects of IUDs Bleeding Most common side effect; physiological bleeding resolves in 1-3 months. Iron supplementation may be needed. Persistent bleeding despite treatment may necessitate IUD removal. Pain Most common cause for removal Managed with analgesics. Resolves in 3 months. Severe pain may indicate uterine perforation (rare). Pelvic inflammatory disease (Option C) Presents with fever, abdominal pain, and discharge. Treatment involves broad-spectrum antibiotics. IUD removal if no improvement. 3rd generation of IUD is protective against IUD. Uterine perforation (Option B) Rare complications linked to immediate postpartum insertion or poor technique. 1st generation IUDs are associated with a higher risk of perforation. Failure of contraception § pregnancy Least pregnancies are reported with MIRENA. If a woman requests an induced abortion – legally allowed. If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are visible: Pull the thread and continue pregnancy. Explain the risk of spontaneous abortion or congenital anomalies. If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are not visible: Uterus examination for any complications. Evacuation of uterus if any complication is identified. If no complication identified , pregnancy can be continued after removal of IUD if the woman desires with increased risk of spontaneous abortion and pre term labour. Ectopic pregnancy (Option D) Recognized by lower abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, or amenorrhea. Women at high risk should avoid IUDs. Expulsion (Option A) Typically occurs within weeks of insertion or during menstruation. Higher risk in young, nulliparous, postpartum women or using 1st generation IUDs Migration of IUD Rarely causes intestinal obstruction. Diagnosed via X-ray imaging if suspected. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 572-4.

questions.question: What is the name of the IUD shown below?
questions.explanation: mm² of copper. 2nd generation IUDs Type Copper containing device Mechanism of action Reduces sperm motility and survival by altering cervical mucus affecting uterine enzymes increasing cellular response in the endometrium Features Strong anti-fertility effect Low expulsion rate Easy to fit in nulliparous women Lesser side effects Effective post-coital contraceptive Side effects Bleeding Pain Pelvic inflammatory disease Uterine perforation Failure of contraception § Pregnancy Ectopic pregnancy Expulsion Migration of IUD CuT 380A 380 mm² of copper wire around a stem with nylon thread attached Shelf life -10 years Nova-T CuT 380 A with a silver (Ag)

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea seeks contraception counseling. She prefers a long-acting reversible contraceptive and is interested in intrauterine devices (IUDs). Which IUD would be the most appropriate choice for her, considering her medical history and preferences?
questions.explanation: heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea, 3rd generation IUD such as Mirena or LNG 20, that releases levonorgestrel and decreases menstrual blood loss is used. The other options are also IUDs, but do not benefit those with heavy menstrual bleeding. Types of IUDs 1 st generation 2 nd generation 3 rd generation Type Inert Copper-containing Hormone containing Examples Lippes loop CuT-380A Mirena (LNG-20) Grafenberg containing ring Nova-T Progestasert Multiload 1st generation IUD 2nd generation IUD 3rd generation IUD Mechanism of action Made of polyethene/other polymers Foreign body reaction causes reduced chances of fertilization Contains copper Copper acts as spermicide Copper changes composition of cervical mucus Releases levonorgestrel Increases cervical mucus thickness Makes endometrium unfavorable for implantation Features Non-medicated High failure rate Highly effective Low failure rate Lowest failure rate among IUDs Decreases menstrual blood loss More expensive Examples Grafenberg ring Lippe’s loop Nova-T (Noncard) Multiload 250. Mirena/LNG-20 (Releases 20 µ g of progesterone per day) Shelf life- 5-8 years Progestasert (Releases 65 µ g of progesterone per day) Shelf life- 1 year Side effects Bleeding, Pain Pelvic inflammatory disease- M/c/c Actinomyces Uterine perforation Failure of contraception § Pregnancy Ectopic pregnancy Expulsion, Migration of IUD

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a form that spermicide is available in?
questions.explanation: jellies, and suppositories, but not as patches. Type of contraception Chemical barrier Mechanism of action Surface-active agents that attach to spermatozoa, inhibiting oxygen uptake and killing them. Available as Creams, Jellies, Pastes, Suppositories & Soluble films Advantages When used in conjunction with barrier methods, offers better pregnancy prevention than if either method were used alone Disadvantages Must be used immediately before intercourse and repeated before each sex act Must be introduced into regions of the vagina where sperm are likely to be deposited May cause burning, irritation, or messiness Failure rate High when used alone Availability Not part of the method mix promoted by the National Family Welfare Programme in India Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th ed Pg 569 - 570

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the contraception shown below?

options.A: It is made of polyurethane foam and saturated with a spermicide nonoxynol-9
options.B: It must be left in place for at least 6 hours after intercourse.
options.C: It offers no protection from sexually transmitted infections.
options.D: It has a lower failure rate in women who have given birth before.

questions.explanation: provided image is the vaginal sponge. The failure rate of the vaginal sponge is higher in parous women - 20 to 40/HWY compared to nulliparous women - 9 to 20/HWY Brand name TODAY Material Small polyurethane foam sponge Mechanism of action Combines barrier and spermicidal methods to prevent conception Saturated with 1000 mg of spermicide ‘Non-oxynol-9’ Technique of use Must be run under water till thoroughly wet before insertion Inserted vaginally and must be ‘placed over the cervix to be effective Must be left in place for 6 hours after ejaculation All sponges must be removed within the time limits specified by the manufacturer (24 hours for Today) Disadvantages No protection from HIV or STDs May lead to Toxic Shock Syndrome if left beyond 24 hours Has to be left for 6 hours post ejaculation Increased risk of yeast infection and UTI Higher failure rate than diaphragm Failure rate Parous women: 20-40 per HWY Nulliparous women: 9-20 per HWY

questions.question: Match the following contraceptives with their appropriate classification CATEGORY 1 CATEGORY 2 A. Spermicide 1. Physiological method B. Grafenberg Ring 2. Chemical barrier method C. Nuva rings 3. IUD D. Tubectomy 4. Hormonal contraceptive E. Coitus interruptus 5. Terminal surgical contraception
questions.explanation: Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and social medicine, 27th edition, Page 569-582
